title: YEAR Network - Technology Transfer theory & Youth

author: Jarno Salonen, VTT Technical Research Centre of Finland

segmentation: I'll give the world to Mr. Arnold Solomon from BT in Finland.
He will be the section leader, so please thank you very much.
Yep, the mic works good, so welcome to the last section we're going to.

We are supposed to talk about technology, transfer theory and youth, but since you probably heard pretty much about theory already during the morning, I think we're going to skip that part and move right along to the practical cases and stuff like that.
The presentation.
So we've got two presentations I'm going to talk about the year network or Association, and then we're going to have Mrs. Stocker, who's going to present some practical cases from the city of grass?
So dear, so, as Robert is already told, I come from BT which is still biggest multi technological applied research organization in Northern Europe.
But since it's pretty cold in Finland, I've gotta side job in Brussels.
I'm a member of year.
The young European associated with.
Searchers.
So what is here?
It all began when a bunch of bunch of young researchers gathered together in TNO in Delft in the Netherlands in 2005 and they had this fantastic idea that.
OK, what if we come up with this magnificent network of young researchers within Europe?
And well, we had a couple of discussions there.
A few things were done and after 1 1/2 years year was established OK.
Took another 1 1/2 years before Belgium managed to get their government organized.
There was some.
Miss understandings and stuff in there so year became official in the end of 2008.
Anyway, it's a non non profit organization and currently we've got about 10 members.
Currently we've got 10 members that have a total of bit over 13,000 employees, of which about roughly let's say 40% are young people.
So we've got a network of four, five, well, five 6000 young people in addition to the old ones there.
There's the year mission, year aims at facilitating the exchange of ideas, best practices and people.
In order to breakdown the national and cultural barriers and to reorganize or reshape the European research area.
There's a list of current members VTT up there and seen that from Norway they've got about 3000 employees each.
Then there's ten of course from the Netherlands.
I've got about 1 1/2 times that.
Then there are a couple of smaller organisations like KCL with 100 or 200 members up to veto, which has 500.
Also in there a couple of 100 from a couple of 100 up to 600 employees.
Every European research and technology organization can be a member, so it's not for individuals.
It's for organisations or the departments of industrial organisations.
The research departments.

If you happen to be interested or your organization well, it costs the annual fees five euros per employee with a minimum of 200 euros and a maximum of 6000 euros, the latest members, Jozef Stefan Institute, and I, see a they've both both being members for almost a year, but not yet I see is in Spain, in Sevilla.
So let's imagine that you you are again or you happen to be a young researcher within within a University or a research organization or a company.

For some of you it might be decades ago, but for some people it might be just the current situation and you've got this fantastic idea that you want to promote and you want to spin off as a as a company or something like that.
Well, of course the first thing that you do is you go to your peers, you go to your network, but what the heck.
You haven't got a network because you're young, you're you're a young researcher, so the issue is your friends are maybe trying to finalize their studies or then they're looking for a job.
OK, quit that idea.
The next thing that you do as an ambitious young researcher, you go to your supervisor or a senior colleague and you describe the idea to him or her.
But the issue is in that case that, OK, they might have some other things to do.
Would not be interested in your topic in your idea or the third thing is that they just doesn't meet their area of professional.
So basically they don't know anything.
What you're talking about.
Well, if that's the case, then you're in deep trouble my friend.
Anyway, the challenge is what you have to do in order to overcome the challenges.
The first of all, you have to gain the experience gained, the scientific and economic performance.
Well, you have to be mobile.
You have to go to another country as a research exchange researcher and try to do and establish your own network.
What you also have to do is you have to.
You have to have the initial training activities which are basically the technology transfer and intrapreneurial skills like Merrick Reactions program has stated.

Another problem is that your organization, whether it's a company or University, they're not necessarily interested in your idea, or they're not interested in the spin of thing, and also what they do, is they expect you to have those intrapreneurial skills automatically, so it's just the snap of a finger, and you're an intrapreneur.
It's not the case.
The young people maybe have the have have the necessary skills.
They've got the risk taking Cape risk taking capabilities.
They've got the motivation.
They are eager enough to do that kind of thing, but they still need support before they become successful.
Technology transfer people.
So how does here fit in this whole equation?
Well, first of all, year provides those initial training things, initial training activities.
First of all, this the networking we organized so far since we started we've organized a couple of networking events.
I'll have a list later in the next slide, and it's not just networking with other people from other countries or without from other organisations.
I participated to half a dozen of the year events as because I've been an active member and I've met other be tears in those events, some 15 or 20 that I didn't know that existed in Finland.
Well, of course, Finland is a large large country and BTE situated in four or five different cities.
So that's obvious thing to happen.
I meet new people and make new friends.
Another thing is news and information.
So basically year offers a newsletter that comes four times per year or three, or four times per year.
It introduces the different organisations that are within year, so it tells you about Veto.
It tells you about T and how it tells you about ISR.
Even Institute Joseph Stephen.
In addition, you've got some information about recent research news, or then it can also introduce individuals.
So basically there's a story about the.
Exchange researcher that went to one place like VTT Finland and tells that, OK, I survived.
It's not so cold in there.
Another thing, mobility we've discussed it was 2007.

We studied the initial discussions with the Human resources Department, managers of different European artios, about researcher mobility, and that's something that we're still trying to negotiate kind of.
Provides support supporting activities for researcher mobility, which is essential for creating the networks at those kinds of things.
The other activities what I mentioned was the training courses.
Well we had, and actually we're trying to develop this into another course.
We had to create course which was based on America Re project started in 2007 and ended this year in the summer.
It comprised of four different training courses, one per year in different locations.
We gathered some 50 to 60 people to a location like Antwerp.
And stayed there for one week with different kinds of people from different fields of research of business.
And the idea was to provide the necessary skills.
So basically it was one course was about creativity and innovation.
Another course was disseminating your research results.
3rd 1/3 course in Munich last year was about technology transfer and knowledge transfer.
Basically the same thing.
And last but not least, in Tron time this year we had the topic human resource management in teams.
We've also got some conferences and other events.
We've organised two annual conferences already.
One was about making money out of research, patenting things.
Those kinds of issues.
The second one was held in Grass Austria last year.
It was about making the recipe of being a smart researcher.
So how to apply funding for your research?
Where to apply funding, how to do contract things and those kinds of issues?

And this year I see that it says to become confirmed, but I see it has already initiated that they've got a draft program and their annual conference year annual conference will be held in the beginning of December and the topic would be getting your research funded by private companies.
Whether you remember or not, you can participate.
OK, non members have to pay a small fee that covers the meals and materials but but that's not much for.
Two day course we've also organized and open Innovation Workshop in 2009.
It's not just some courses.
We had the guru of open innovation being 1/2 a Baker as a keynote speaker.
He lives close to Eindhoven, where we held the conference or the workshop.
So he came there and gave us a speech on electron open innovation.
And last but not least, a networking event which was held in autonomy in Helsinki close to the Nokia headquarters last year and will also be held this year about at the same location.

The idea is to bring different people from universities, different people from research and technology organisations and companies to discuss about recent issues like like economic crisis, how to survive those and make new Contacts.
That's one of the most import.
Good things.

So to summarize here, supports young professionals in technology transfer and other issues activities through information, through training courses and providing possibilities for networking and mobility.
The beneficiaries, as in young professionals and their employers, which artios companies in wealth industrial research bodies.
At least the researchers have been really pleased with the courses and the events that we've organized.
However, what I mentioned, as well as the last point supporting actions also from the company or the University or the RTO, is really important.
We need more professionals.
We need more seniors to participate and give us lectures, provide their information and transfer their knowledge to the young people.
And also we need RTO commitment, especially RTO.
It's better in the companies, but artios and universities they currently don't commit so well in the long run.
So basically they accept an individual course, but when you try to negotiate with them that OK, we need to have other courses.
Also the person the young professional has to participate to this.
This amount of courses in order to get the whole picture then.
That's currently an issue, but we're working on this.
As the last picture, I've got a, I've got a situation from Antwerp from our create course.
We gathered there in with the topic of dissemination of research results and in the same time we were discussing also about the information flow within an organization.
So basically we had an example of a traditional organizational structure.
Well, the tree based where the manager was at the top and the individual researcher was at the bottom.
So the information flow wasn't that good when we were given a task of some kind with secret information and something.

Could be given to this direction, but something couldn't be told to the other, but then we had another concrete example of if anyone can talk to anyone in the organization, how much better the information flows.
Just something to provide you with an idea that about the events of the training that we've.
OK, thanks, that was my pot.
Any any questions?
Yep.
It's for young.
They don't have a scientific.
Yeah, well, it's been said that it's industrial research body, but basically you can always define yourself into having one.
So it's not a big issue.

It's an industrial organization, of course, because we were we were initially we were applying for funding and when we defined for example in the beginning we define that a young professional is from the age of 20, something to the age of 37.
But if I show.
Are you this picture?
He he was.
He was about 45 at this stage so so we've accepted seniors also.
It's not an issue.
We always say that it's your in either young physically or than you are young at mind.
Other questions.
Yeah, actually there was.
I don't know personally, but there was supposed to be a presentation of year in the last year or conference.
I wasn't giving it so I don't know about it.
But I heard that at least one of us was going there.
I think it was Miss Barbara Beer, but her from you on now she was at least supposed to give the presentation anyway.
We've got actually that conduct also came through that create course.
There was one Euro Doc active member and he started initiating the discussion and we organize some kind of cooperation and also with other with other networks.
OK.
Thanks.
